did.abstract: John M. Budarz was one of the founders of the Polish Art League of Pittsburgh and held the presidency of the organization twice. Mr. Budarz was also active in the American Council of Polish Cultural Clubs, an umbrella organization for various cultural clubs on the national level. Material in this collection relates to activities of Polish Arts League of Pittsburgh, information on numerous cultural events, correspondence, and includes publication of their newsletter - Palette.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: John M. Budarz, 1906-1994, born in Windsor, Conn., graduate of Norwich University in Vermont and the Law School of Duquesne University in Pittsburgh. Mr. Budarz was one of the founding members, long time officer, treasurer and twice president of the Polish Arts League of Pittsburgh. He worked in the insurance business and the Consulate of the Republic of Poland (1921-1945). He was active in the American Council of Polish Cultural Clubs, serving as a vice-president, treasurer and chairman of several committees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents of the Collection
scopecontent.p: The Polish Arts League of Pittsburgh was created in 1948 to promote Polish Culture and tradition and to support Polish and American authors, artists, and performers. It is an affiliate of the American Council of Polish Culture (formerly American Council of Polish Cultural Clubs) and twice was a host of its national convention. Over the years it organized numerous concerts, lectures, performances, exhibitions, festivals, etc. It established special scholarship, published monthly newsletter called Palette, conducted educational campaigns, and cooperated with various Polish American organizations. It regularly brought shows from Poland. Twice, in 1953 and 1988 it organized the presentation of Moniszko's opera "Halka". This collection consists of correspondence, reports, announcements, financial records, constitutions and by-laws, membership lists, newsletter, newspaper clippings, and pamphlets covering the years 1948-1989.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
